<html><body><div><div class="RichTextArticleBody RichTextBody">
    
      <p>BRAINERD — The two men arrested Jan. 26 by the Department of Homeland Security at the now-for-sale El Potro Mexican Restaurant in downtown Brainerd were indicted in federal court.</p><p>According to federal court documents, on Thursday, Jan. 29, Francisco Javier Montoya-Barboza, 35, was charged with one count of improper entry of an alien, a misdemeanor, and Jose Barajas-Farias, 52, was charged with reentry of a removed alien, a felony. Both are detained in the Douglas County Jail in Superior, Wisconsin. Both Montoya-Barboza and Barajas-Farias entered a plea of not guilty.</p>
    
      
    
      <p>According to information received by KAXE Northern Community Radio through a data request with Immigration and Customs Enforcement and shared with the Dispatch, ICE named two men arrested with warrants and two men arrested without warrants. The names provided by ICE in multiple data requests contained errors in spelling and formatting. The names of those involved were independently verified with the assistance of KAXE.</p><p>The Crow Wing County Sheriff’s Office previously reported 
    
      <a class="Link " href="https://www.brainerddispatch.com/news/local/federal-agents-arrest-4-at-brainerd-restaurant" target="_blank" data-cms-ai="0">deputies assisted</a>
    
       the Department of Homeland Security with the arrests on Jan. 26.</p><p>The data request from ICE stated on Jan. 26, ICE agents in Brainerd executed judicial criminal arrest warrants for two men, both illegal aliens wanted on federal immigration charges.</p><p>The data request stated Montoya-Barboza was previously convicted of driving while under the influence. Minnesota court records show he was convicted in March 2011 of liquor consumption by a person under the age of 21 from a December 2010 arrest.</p><p>ICE described Montoya-Barboza and Barajas-Farias as its “primary subjects.” No warrants existed for the other two men who were arrested.</p><p>The two other men who were taken into custody Jan. 26, were detained at the Crow Wing County Jail on Jan. 27. The Brainerd Dispatch found a record of only one of the two men taken without warrants being in custody at the Crow Wing County Jail as of Tuesday, Feb. 2. Because neither has been charged with a crime the Dispatch is declining to name them. ICE reported the two men are being detained pending removal proceedings.</p><p>An amended arrest warrant issued for Montoya-Barboza filed Jan. 14, 2026, in Minnesota U.S. District Court listed improper entry of an alien as the offense.</p>
    
      
    
      <p>The warrant was issued based on an indictment. Montoya-Barboza’s indictment stated on Dec. 22, 2025, he was found in the U.S. after having entered at a place other than designated by immigration officers in violation of Title 8.</p><p>The arrest warrant issued for Barajas-Farias filed Jan. 13, 2026, in Minnesota U.S. District Court listed reentry of a removed alien as the offense.</p><p>That warrant also was issued based on an indictment. Barajas-Farias’ indictment stated on Dec. 18, 2025, he was found in the U.S. after having been removed on/or about June 3, 2005, and March 16, 2006, without the express consent of the U.S. Attorney General or the Secretary of Homeland Security, in violation of Title 8.</p>
    
      
    
      <p></p>
    
</div>

            
          
          


          <div class="Page-authorInfo">
        

        
            
        

        
            <div class="Page-authorInfo-bio" data-type="small"><p>

            </p></div>
        

        
            
        
    </div>



          
            </div></body></html>
